headline: J.B. Hunt Transport Services, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: Ladies and gentlemen, please welcome your speaker for today, Mr. David Mee. Sir, you may begin.
componenttext: Ladies and gentlemen, please welcome your speaker for today, Mr. David Mee. Sir, you may begin.

headline: J.B. Hunt Transport Services, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Donna. Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for joining us. We have here, John Roberts, President and CEO; Jerry Matthews, President of Intermodal; Nick Hobbs, President of DCS; Shelley Simpson, Chief Commercial Officer and President of High
componenttext:
Thank you, Donna. Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for joining us. We have here, John Roberts, President and CEO; Jerry Matthews, President of Intermodal; Nick Hobbs, President of DCS; Shelley Simpson, Chief Commercial Officer and President of Highway Services; and myself, David Mee. 
Given that this is our first earnings call, let me kind of go over, what we'd like the format to be. I'll make a brief opening statements, and then we'll open up the lines for Q&A. Participants will have an opportunity to ask a question and then 1 follow up, before they have to return to the end of the queue to give everybody a shot at asking the questions that they want. We do have a call scheduled for 90 minutes. So we hope to get through as many questions as we can during that time. And we do appreciate your patience, given that this is the first time we've attempted this. If we go forward, I'm sure, we'll be a lot more efficient into the future.
As far as the opening remarks, I have 2 areas that I want to address. The first is, quarterly tax rate and the difference between the preannounced after-tax charge and the actual after-tax charge reported in the earnings release. The primary in the reduced rates are our annual computation of what is referred to as our FIN 48 exposure, and a tax rate adjustment for equity-based compensation. 
At the time of the arbitration update announcement last week, we had not performed these reconciliations and had not determined the discrete item amounts. So we used our previous estimated quarterly tax rate of 26% instead of the 20.4% that Q3 ultimately generated. With this third quarter adjustment and our current estimate of what our discrete items will be in fourth quarter, we anticipate that our full year 2018 tax rate will be 24%.
The second area is, obviously the elephant in the room, the arbitration update. And as we announced, we received the interim award on October 5, 2018. The interim award is subject to a protective order, addressing among other things, the confidentiality of the award to the underlying contract. However in that intermodal, we were able to identify a quantifiable point for a specific issue that occurred over multiple period, that was the $18 million pretax charge, we announced. We also stated that arbitration analyst requested additional submissions from the parties over the next several months. These submissions are needed to determine a, an appropriate interim awards; and b, a final award. We cannot determine any further financial implications of the interim award beyond the $18 million announced precharge, until after the arbitrators review the additional information required to be submitted issue an additional interim award or final award. Once we can determine any additional financial impact of any interim award or final awards, we'll provide additional disclosure at that time.
Until then, we will follow what has been our standard practice during this entire process, which is, what we said in the press release is all we're going to say. So any questions on the arbitration process or on this interim award will most likely be answered with no comment, it is confidential or we have said all we're going to say or something similar. 
Now as we do when the investor community visits our headquarters. We've assembled the entire management team to answer your questions and talk about their businesses. 
With that, Donna, we're now ready to take our first question.

headline: J.B. Hunt Transport Services, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Mr. Amit Mehrotra.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Mr. Amit Mehrotra.

headline: J.B. Hunt Transport Services, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: First one is just, if you can talk about the deceleration in intermodal volume growth, basically every quarter this year, I fully understand that we have the derailment in the quarter, which likely impacted the number. But does the deceleration, I would i
componenttext: First one is just, if you can talk about the deceleration in intermodal volume growth, basically every quarter this year, I fully understand that we have the derailment in the quarter, which likely impacted the number. But does the deceleration, I would imagine, impact some price over volume focus of the management team, could you just talk about that? When do you guys expect, you did pull the volume lever or volumes to reaccelerate, just given the tight truckload market?

headline: J.B. Hunt Transport Services, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: Obviously, this year, we've been focused a lot on price, and I think you're seeing the results of that in the marketplace. It's been a marketplace, that I believe has been the most orderly marketplace, I've seen in the 28 years, I've been involved in Inte
componenttext: Obviously, this year, we've been focused a lot on price, and I think you're seeing the results of that in the marketplace. It's been a marketplace, that I believe has been the most orderly marketplace, I've seen in the 28 years, I've been involved in Intermodal. And I think that will continue into next year. With regards to volume, as you look in 2019, I think, you'll see a better balance between price and volume as we go forward, and we'll have a more balanced approach as we hit 2019.

headline: J.B. Hunt Transport Services, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: Could you talk about what do you estimate the volume impact to be from the 5 major derailments in the quarter?
componenttext: Could you talk about what do you estimate the volume impact to be from the 5 major derailments in the quarter?

headline: J.B. Hunt Transport Services, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: I believe it was around 4,000, 5,000 units.
componenttext: I believe it was around 4,000, 5,000 units.

headline: J.B. Hunt Transport Services, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: Got it. That's helpful. And just as a follow up, I guess, it was nice to see that step-up in incremental margins in the third quarter, over 20% kind of an underlying basis. Is that the right level to expect kind of over the next 3, 4 quarters, just given,
componenttext: Got it. That's helpful. And just as a follow up, I guess, it was nice to see that step-up in incremental margins in the third quarter, over 20% kind of an underlying basis. Is that the right level to expect kind of over the next 3, 4 quarters, just given, as some of the pricing actions continue to cycle through the numbers. Is that sort of the right incremental margins you guys are targeting for the Intermodal business over the next several quarters?

headline: J.B. Hunt Transport Services, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: I think that's good -- I mean, this is David Mee. I think that's going to be the result, given that the fact is that we will begin, I mean, pricing calendar here in the fourth quarter, but the effects of those new pricing's won't show up until later in th
componenttext: I think that's good -- I mean, this is David Mee. I think that's going to be the result, given that the fact is that we will begin, I mean, pricing calendar here in the fourth quarter, but the effects of those new pricing's won't show up until later in the 2019. So yes, I would say that the pricing is set. So operationally, if we can squeeze a little bit margin out of fit, out of operations, then we will. But I wouldn't expect much difference in what you're seeing here in Q3.

componenttext: Got it. And then a quick follow up as well. I think that the way this data came out just this morning about spot truck rates continuing to fall. Do you guys think that this is mainly because of a pull forward of freight, which created kind of an artificial high, which we're now seeing to tail off. Or maybe do you think there's something else at work that's causing these spot trucking rates to continue to fall?

headline: J.B. Hunt Transport Services, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: Great question. This is Shelley. We have similar questions. We have been talking with our customers. We do know that some customers have done a forward strategy that I can't say that we've got a great answer to what that question is. We have intermodal cu
componenttext: Great question. This is Shelley. We have similar questions. We have been talking with our customers. We do know that some customers have done a forward strategy that I can't say that we've got a great answer to what that question is. We have intermodal customers that are expecting a good peak retail season that they are still considering to be good and so we would expect to have a pretty good peak as we come into intermodal, finishing the first leg and then truckload coming after that.

But can you give us a read on what the volume growth look like in Intermodal by month? And then, what the start for October is, in terms of just, I think, low growth year-over-year?

headline: J.B. Hunt Transport Services, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: Tom, I'll take historical stuff, and then I'll let Terry tell you about how he feels so far in October, since it's too early. I don't tell you what the numbers are current anyway. July was up 4% year-over-year, not calendar affected. August was down 1% ye
componenttext: Tom, I'll take historical stuff, and then I'll let Terry tell you about how he feels so far in October, since it's too early. I don't tell you what the numbers are current anyway. July was up 4% year-over-year, not calendar affected. August was down 1% year-over-year, again, not calendar affected and September was down 2% year-over-year, again not calendar affected, that's how we get to our 1% up. As far as really, our peak season has started off, we've seen the West Coast pickup the last week or so in September, and basically the peak is hitting our expectation similar to what we've seen in the past here so far in October. We think the next 4 to 6 weeks up through Thanksgiving should be very normal -- that would be a very normal peak, and we're also thinking that December with possible tariff implications should be extremely strong in December as well.

headline: J.B. Hunt Transport Services, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: So how do you think about the relationship between spot market, and what you are seeing and then what that might imply for next year. So I guess, we've seen that softness in the truckload spot market, but it sounds like you're expecting a good seasonal pi
componenttext: So how do you think about the relationship between spot market, and what you are seeing and then what that might imply for next year. So I guess, we've seen that softness in the truckload spot market, but it sounds like you're expecting a good seasonal pickup. So does that imply that the spot data should be stronger as we get into kind of later October, November? And then I guess, if that doesn't play out that you see continued weakness in the spot metric. Does that give you concern that you're going to lose some leverage as you go into the contract negotiations in peak season for 2019?

headline: J.B. Hunt Transport Services, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: I would say customers have finished their bid seasons here through the third quarter with implementation. I know a lot of our customers were working towards getting more in the contract business. So they paid higher rate in that taken somewhat by surprise
componenttext: I would say customers have finished their bid seasons here through the third quarter with implementation. I know a lot of our customers were working towards getting more in the contract business. So they paid higher rate in that taken somewhat by surprise. Understood that the asset players needed more contract rate. They're willing to give that up, and I think you've seen part of it happen from the bid cycle being fully implemented in total.

headline: J.B. Hunt Transport Services, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: The other thing I would mention -- this is Terry, that the -- as much as we tried to keep up with the truck rates, we did a pretty good job there, but the fuel surcharge has gone up substantially over the last year. And when you look at the differential b
componenttext: The other thing I would mention -- this is Terry, that the -- as much as we tried to keep up with the truck rates, we did a pretty good job there, but the fuel surcharge has gone up substantially over the last year. And when you look at the differential between all-in fuel and the truck rate versus what the intermodal rate is, there still a pretty good gap there. So I think that bodes well for intermodal.

headline: J.B. Hunt Transport Services, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: Okay. So it sounds like you're not overly concerned about the spot market weakness in product in terms of impact to intermodal rate?
componenttext: Okay. So it sounds like you're not overly concerned about the spot market weakness in product in terms of impact to intermodal rate?

componenttext: No.

componenttextpreview: Just a bit more on pricing and contract repricing. You mentioned, as you're starting up the season again in the fourth quarter. What type of rate increases are you guiding your customers towards in 2019, and how those conversations are going?
componenttext: Just a bit more on pricing and contract repricing. You mentioned, as you're starting up the season again in the fourth quarter. What type of rate increases are you guiding your customers towards in 2019, and how those conversations are going?

headline: J.B. Hunt Transport Services, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: So I think that depends customer by customer. We have started talking with them about the costs creep that is occurring, and that depends by customer and what that really looks like. It also depends on when they really came into the bid cycle with us. So
componenttext: So I think that depends customer by customer. We have started talking with them about the costs creep that is occurring, and that depends by customer and what that really looks like. It also depends on when they really came into the bid cycle with us. So we saw cost continued to creep after we started the bid cycle last year, and so some of those customers were in different conversations with versus customers that have just completed their bids.

headline: J.B. Hunt Transport Services, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: Okay. Is it reasonable to still expect above average rate increases next year, if that's a way of asking that versus historical norm?
componenttext: Okay. Is it reasonable to still expect above average rate increases next year, if that's a way of asking that versus historical norm?

headline: J.B. Hunt Transport Services, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: We think that our -- we still have cost challenges. We are talking to our customers about those and recouping those during bid season. Historical norm, I'm not sure what that number is for you, but I would expect customers to be able to manage measures th
componenttext: We think that our -- we still have cost challenges. We are talking to our customers about those and recouping those during bid season. Historical norm, I'm not sure what that number is for you, but I would expect customers to be able to manage measures that are coming into next year, not being as surprised, being in the spot market as much. But they will still be paying more than really what any of us want to pay based on cost changes that are still happening.

headline: J.B. Hunt Transport Services, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: And then just one quick follow up from me on the tax rate. As we look into '19, is 26% still the right number to use for '19? Or is there a step change now associated?
componenttext: And then just one quick follow up from me on the tax rate. As we look into '19, is 26% still the right number to use for '19? Or is there a step change now associated?

headline: J.B. Hunt Transport Services, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: Yes, I at this point in time, I'll tell you 26% is going to be the number. Again, we'll have discrete items with both the stock compensation and the FIN 48. Stock compensation is affected by stock price, so if the stock price goes up or down that will cha
componenttext: Yes, I at this point in time, I'll tell you 26% is going to be the number. Again, we'll have discrete items with both the stock compensation and the FIN 48. Stock compensation is affected by stock price, so if the stock price goes up or down that will change that baseline amount up or down accordingly with stock price. And then FIN 48 is going to be based on income levels in the states that we have uncertain tax positions in. So it's very difficult to predict on front-end basis. So my budget, we'll use 26% until we figure out what the exact discrete items look like.

headline: J.B. Hunt Transport Services, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your next question comes from the line of Mr. Brad
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your next question comes from the line of Mr. Brad

headline: J.B. Hunt Transport Services, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: A question for Nick. Nick, could you -- I know you talk about the dedicated start-up costs, but when we you make the adjustments that were sort of outlined in the release and add back $4 million of quantified start-up cost, you get to like 91 3 OR, and I
componenttext: A question for Nick. Nick, could you -- I know you talk about the dedicated start-up costs, but when we you make the adjustments that were sort of outlined in the release and add back $4 million of quantified start-up cost, you get to like 91 3 OR, and I don't think that's necessary your steady-state going forward. So can you talk about the kind of cadence of what you think the operating ratio should do, assuming you don't have anything other than the start-up costs you've quantified for Q4 and Q1?

headline: J.B. Hunt Transport Services, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: I think, first thing is the startup cost is a lot of stuff around pay, hiring charges, training charges, so a lot of those in there. But the other thing to keep in mind, Brad, is that's not a normal cadence. Our cadence would be more in the 11% to 13% mar
componenttext: I think, first thing is the startup cost is a lot of stuff around pay, hiring charges, training charges, so a lot of those in there. But the other thing to keep in mind, Brad, is that's not a normal cadence. Our cadence would be more in the 11% to 13% margin range and that's what our base business is running. And I think the other thing, when you're looking at the global dedicated, you have to take into account Final Mile is starting to grow some, and so there is little bit of delusion that goes on with that as well from an OR Not a great amount, but it does drag it down a little bit. But it's just the timing of when all of them come home, and when they go out and trying to estimate that. If you look at just our base business that's out of startup, it is performing in our accepted margins. And so we just got a bunch of trucks. We've got 600 trucks that we added from the end of Q2 to the end of Q3, which is a lot. So that $4 million that we put in there, that's some very big items. There is lot of little items associated with that. So each one of them is different, but I would think, you'd see the OR start heading back where it needed to be in Q1, and then Q2 of next year, as we get some more big awards.

headline: J.B. Hunt Transport Services, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: And then, Dave for you, just 2 small nitpicky follow ups. The bankruptcy that you guys commented on, I'm assuming that's related to 1 from last year. Can you quantify if there is any exposure to 1 that's been very recently announced, if any? And then numb
componenttext: And then, Dave for you, just 2 small nitpicky follow ups. The bankruptcy that you guys commented on, I'm assuming that's related to 1 from last year. Can you quantify if there is any exposure to 1 that's been very recently announced, if any? And then number two to the follow up. Can you tell us when that 4,000 load impacted hit which month in intermodal?

componenttextpreview: Yes, the intermodal impact was the end of mainly August, but the first week in September, when the past had the major derailments and the 3 major lines went out. It's August 21, but it's taken them 3 or 4 weeks, so it has led into September, but it was pr
componenttext: Yes, the intermodal impact was the end of mainly August, but the first week in September, when the past had the major derailments and the 3 major lines went out. It's August 21, but it's taken them 3 or 4 weeks, so it has led into September, but it was primarily August and the first 10 days of September.

headline: J.B. Hunt Transport Services, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: And then, as far as your bankruptcy, that 1 particular one did occur this year. It was with a store that was competing with the Dollar stores. We've had them as customer for quite a while, but they decided to expand into the Northeast and we grew with the
componenttext: And then, as far as your bankruptcy, that 1 particular one did occur this year. It was with a store that was competing with the Dollar stores. We've had them as customer for quite a while, but they decided to expand into the Northeast and we grew with them. And it turned out that it wasn't the most advantageous decision for either one of us at this point in time. As far as the one that happened wasn't today, by any chance. We have virtually no exposure to that one.

headline: J.B. Hunt Transport Services, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: Brad, and a follow up, we had hurricane Florence in September. So we derailments bleed in from August to September and then hurricane affected the Carolinas.
componenttext: Brad, and a follow up, we had hurricane Florence in September. So we derailments bleed in from August to September and then hurricane affected the Carolinas.

headline: J.B. Hunt Transport Services, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask about what your thoughts initially are on the potential short and long-term impact from precision railroading potentially being rolled out in across the U.S. rail?
componenttext: I wanted to ask about what your thoughts initially are on the potential short and long-term impact from precision railroading potentially being rolled out in across the U.S. rail?

headline: J.B. Hunt Transport Services, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: This is Terry again. The precision railroading obviously to Hunter Harrison is the pioneer of that. And I think, what you're seeing is, each railroad is taking bits and pieces and trying to implement things that they think that fit within their railroads
componenttext: This is Terry again. The precision railroading obviously to Hunter Harrison is the pioneer of that. And I think, what you're seeing is, each railroad is taking bits and pieces and trying to implement things that they think that fit within their railroads without going overboard with regards to maybe what the CSX did in going all out in the precision railroading. Some of the effects that could happen are some of the rationalization that goes on. They like big long trains and some of the shorter markets, they have announced, I think in January, there is a few things that will be discontinued, and I think that's probably the key thing that's we're focused on, trying to figure out what does that exactly mean? Can we use a different route? Can we use a different railroad? Can we have a longer dray. But I believe that'll -- there probably be less options than more, and hopefully this service will get back to where we all expect it to be and where they want it be in some form or fashion.

headline: J.B. Hunt Transport Services, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then following up, how does 360 play a roll in this, if at all. And then could you give us a sense for your initial expectations for rail purchase trends in '19? And maybe some color on your initial thoughts on margins for JBI?
componenttext: Okay. And then following up, how does 360 play a roll in this, if at all. And then could you give us a sense for your initial expectations for rail purchase trends in '19? And maybe some color on your initial thoughts on margins for JBI?

headline: J.B. Hunt Transport Services, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: So we'll be integrating the dray piece on JBI into the platform in 2019. And so any carriers that we do dray with, which will be about 15%-or-so of our shipments, will be contracting through our 360 platform that's scheduled to come online mid-year next y
componenttext: So we'll be integrating the dray piece on JBI into the platform in 2019. And so any carriers that we do dray with, which will be about 15%-or-so of our shipments, will be contracting through our 360 platform that's scheduled to come online mid-year next year.

headline: J.B. Hunt Transport Services, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: Yes, the JDI, traditionally, we've been trying to have 11% to 13% margin. I think we're somewhere in that range now, and we hope we can be able to As far as next year, we're in the budgeting process, and we really don't have any hard numbers yet to be abl
componenttext: Yes, the JDI, traditionally, we've been trying to have 11% to 13% margin. I think we're somewhere in that range now, and we hope we can be able to As far as next year, we're in the budgeting process, and we really don't have any hard numbers yet to be able to tell you what's going on with box orders or equipment for 2019.

headline: J.B. Hunt Transport Services, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: Okay. And does that do you have any -- sorry, for the background noise. Any thoughts on the rail cost next year versus 2018?
componenttext: Okay. And does that do you have any -- sorry, for the background noise. Any thoughts on the rail cost next year versus 2018?

headline: J.B. Hunt Transport Services, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: No. I mean, each year there's rail cost increases, and at this point, it doesn't look any different than what it has in the years past.
componenttext: No. I mean, each year there's rail cost increases, and at this point, it doesn't look any different than what it has in the years past.

headline: J.B. Hunt Transport Services, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2018

componenttext: The next question comes from the line of Chris Wetherbee.

headline: J.B. Hunt Transport Services, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: Wanted to ask about the DCS segment. So I guess, I'm thinking about 2019 and the environment that we're able to see in there, that there's likely to be a continued push for shippers to get capacity. So in that context, if you think about a good amount of
componenttext: Wanted to ask about the DCS segment. So I guess, I'm thinking about 2019 and the environment that we're able to see in there, that there's likely to be a continued push for shippers to get capacity. So in that context, if you think about a good amount of potential fleet conversion of growth of the segment, do you think you can sort of stabilize and move margins higher. I guess, really the question is, can you get margins moving upward, if you're still experiencing strong revenue growth, I'm trying to get a sense how that relationship looks in 2019?

headline: J.B. Hunt Transport Services, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think our plan -- our focus is try not to get as much -- we really don't focus on capacity fleets. We try to focus on private fleet convergence. We will get a little bit of that capacity with some of our historical legacy customers. But I think, we
componenttext: Yes, I think our plan -- our focus is try not to get as much -- we really don't focus on capacity fleets. We try to focus on private fleet convergence. We will get a little bit of that capacity with some of our historical legacy customers. But I think, we will plan on probably not adding as many trucks next year, we added this year. I think a good number of trucks for us to add is between 1,000 and 1,200, and that's probably our plan is going to be for next year. This year, we're going to add a whole lot more than that, and so I think it will slow down and we call it the way from '18 will help carry some of the better margin in middle part to the end of next year. So I think, you will see some margin improvement. But if we happen to get another big deals signed up, where we signed up little over 500 truck deal this year and some other larger deals in our pipeline that we've signed that's in the middle of implementing, if does come along, it could be a little bit of a drag. But right now our plan is sort of 1,000 to 1,200 trucks next year.

headline: J.B. Hunt Transport Services, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: Okay, okay, that's helpful. And then on Intermodal, I guess, the middle of last year, it would seem that volume growth has been lower than what your traditional run rates have gotten, I appreciate the large number, so I know there are some mathematical fo
componenttext: Okay, okay, that's helpful. And then on Intermodal, I guess, the middle of last year, it would seem that volume growth has been lower than what your traditional run rates have gotten, I appreciate the large number, so I know there are some mathematical forces that play here. and clearly this rail service issues, all of those factors. But when you think out again to the drivers behind that sort of lower volume growth. Do you think these are more sustainable in that, as we move into '19 and especially beyond, we should expect sort of structurally lower pace of volume growth in the network? Or are they sort of like we saw with some of the derailments that you've this quarter and other factors that played out over the course of '18 might go away and you can see that run rate kind of move back up. I'm thinking more conceptually about your ability to grow in that segment really been the specifics, so it'll be helpful?

headline: J.B. Hunt Transport Services, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: Yes, the bucket of freight that we see in our bid and data warehouse is in the millions of loads, in the East being a bigger portion of that bucket and maybe the West, even though both markets are in millions of loads. So it's just a question of when the
componenttext: Yes, the bucket of freight that we see in our bid and data warehouse is in the millions of loads, in the East being a bigger portion of that bucket and maybe the West, even though both markets are in millions of loads. So it's just a question of when the customers feel comfortable of moving that freight from intermodal -- excuse me, truck over to intermodal, and some years, it's a quicker transition than others. So I hesitate thinking that the story is over, because it's easy to say that the ability -- the way it comes out. So a little increase in rail service, and I think the cost of trucks will continue to increase. I think our ability to able to grow in the Intermodal segment, maybe not as the percentage level that we talked about, there is still is good for the upcoming years.

headline: J.B. Hunt Transport Services, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Ravi Shanker.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Ravi Shanker.

headline: J.B. Hunt Transport Services, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: Couple of questions here. Going back to the current freight environment. Since we aren't really seeing the kind of the uptake and kind of spot rates and market tightness that you expect going into peak season. It does seem like shippers are more comfortab
componenttext: Couple of questions here. Going back to the current freight environment. Since we aren't really seeing the kind of the uptake and kind of spot rates and market tightness that you expect going into peak season. It does seem like shippers are more comfortable than we would expect it to be, given the start of the year. Is that how you're seeing it. And kind of what impact does that have on the brokerage environment, given that a relatively balanced market kind of tends to be a headwind to shippers using brokers?

headline: J.B. Hunt Transport Services, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: So I think that customers, this time last year, were really trying to figure out how to budget and we had sent out a customer letter in August, really trying to articulate our cost position and trying to guide them on budgets. And I think customers took s
componenttext: So I think that customers, this time last year, were really trying to figure out how to budget and we had sent out a customer letter in August, really trying to articulate our cost position and trying to guide them on budgets. And I think customers took several months to try to figure that out. And if you think about the hurricane tapping this time last year, the network was in such a chaos that it was not only difficult to find a truck to move the shipment or capacity, but also the price. And as customers came to this season, I think customers started to understand and we're very receptive to talking about capacity and what prices look like. I think customers are more comfortable today, because they've made it through this season. They feel like they have a good plan. I think they probably take to really good providers to really reset themselves for a successful 2019. And so at the beginning of this year, customers still weren't sure how high pricing would go. And if service would be acceptable or not. And the conversations we're having now, customers are still concerned about service, less concerned about cost, although I've never met a customer that wants an increased cost they understand that underperforming in the market and they really understand what's driving specifically with drivers. So I think they are more comfortable than what they were back in the day. And customers have really done a good job coming out of the spot market and being in contract relationships.

headline: J.B. Hunt Transport Services, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: Got it. And just sticking with ICS. Can you just talk about JB 360 costs, and kind of how they are -- how they've been trending through the quarter and kind of where do you see them in the next couple of quarters?
componenttext: Got it. And just sticking with ICS. Can you just talk about JB 360 costs, and kind of how they are -- how they've been trending through the quarter and kind of where do you see them in the next couple of quarters?

componenttextpreview: Well, they're increasing. I haven't really put together the 2019 plan yet. We have thoughts with what we want from that, so we are working on our budgeting here in the next month or so, so we can start planning for those resources.
componenttext: Well, they're increasing. I haven't really put together the 2019 plan yet. We have thoughts with what we want from that, so we are working on our budgeting here in the next month or so, so we can start planning for those resources.

componenttext: We don't comment on the quarter, but I would tell you that yes, Terry has said, and what he did say is that we're about where we expected to be maybe slightly a little bit ahead, but nothing on the screen that we're seeing things just runoff the chart.

componenttext: Terry, I wanted to come back to the comment you made about 2019 and kind of having more balanced between volume and price on the Intermodal side. componenttext: Okay. And -- but it is fair to think about the fact that the rates that are resetting in the second half of this year, you get to carry forward of that into next year, and if it's still positive pricing environment environment, at least directionally that's a decent way to think about revenue pull out into 2019 and this point?

componenttextpreview: Yes, you're correct.
componenttext: Yes, you're correct.

headline: J.B. Hunt Transport Services, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: Okay, good. And then maybe just kind of a short-term question as we think about the fourth quarter. If we go back, and David maybe this is for you, kind of a high level. But if we adjust for the charges here for this quarter. At this point -- in the third
componenttext: Okay, good. And then maybe just kind of a short-term question as we think about the fourth quarter. If we go back, and David maybe this is for you, kind of a high level. But if we adjust for the charges here for this quarter. At this point -- in the third quarter, is there anything that we should think about as to why we wouldn't see may be kind of what you would normally see from the third quarter into fourth quarter, either some additional cost coming through on the rail service side? Or as you sit here today and we think about you kind of think about how to think about fourth quarter for the rest of the year, is it fair to think about normal fourth quarter trends versus third quarter kind of typical seasonality or is there something else we should be factoring into our assumptions?

headline: J.B. Hunt Transport Services, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: Well, yes, I think the general trend for Intermodal should be fairly consistent. I think that our expectation, like we said, the customers are telling us there is going to be a normalized peak. You're not going to get the that's obviously the last year's
componenttext: Well, yes, I think the general trend for Intermodal should be fairly consistent. I think that our expectation, like we said, the customers are telling us there is going to be a normalized peak. You're not going to get the that's obviously the last year's hurricane wave come in, in spite of that we don't expect to get, it could show up, but we're not counting on it as an item. In Dedicated, I think, they will see their seasonal operations, and so they would expect a seasonal rise, probably a little more so than normal, because frankly, ICS lost some of their seasonal activity to DCS. One of the big or the big contract inside DCS was a direct result of cross-selling, and there is a little bit of robbing Peter to pay Paul, so ICS have to backfill to get to its normal seasonal update in Q4. Considering they gave a bunch of their freight to DCS this year. And then Truckload is actually starting to perform very well inside the seasonal market, relatively speaking. So I think the trend is going to be okay. I couldn't tell you that I see any abnormal cost from the horizon. So I'm hoping that trend is again as predicted, but we're hoping that pricing covers that trend as it did 3Q.

headline: J.B. Hunt Transport Services, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: Okay, that make sense. And I think the biggest piece really is just typical when you see that improved OR  in the fourth quarter and the Intermodal side of that really drive some of the seasonality, and it sounds like that's on track and that's helpful. O
componenttext: Okay, that make sense. And I think the biggest piece really is just typical when you see that improved OR  in the fourth quarter and the Intermodal side of that really drive some of the seasonality, and it sounds like that's on track and that's helpful. On kind of interplay between ICS and DCS, as we think about the fourth quarter.

componenttext: Yes, we should see our total number go up in the range of 98, 100 to 99, 100 is where we'll end the year with trucks and books.

headline: J.B. Hunt Transport Services, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. And then kind of a higher level DCS question. If we think about this, the incremental growth that you're seeing this year. How much of it would you attribute to a tighter overall truckload market versus the continuation of converting
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. And then kind of a higher level DCS question. If we think about this, the incremental growth that you're seeing this year. How much of it would you attribute to a tighter overall truckload market versus the continuation of converting private fleets and also maybe taking some share from your competitors, trying to get a feel for how much of it is just blocking and tackling on the competitive side versus a function of a tighter overall truck market?

headline: J.B. Hunt Transport Services, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: Yes, I would say probably 70% of it is more private fleet blocking and tackling basic stuff. The other 30% is probably because of the tightening capacity with some of the stuff we got from ICS going into long-term contract with us, but also just our base
componenttext: Yes, I would say probably 70% of it is more private fleet blocking and tackling basic stuff. The other 30% is probably because of the tightening capacity with some of the stuff we got from ICS going into long-term contract with us, but also just our base fleets are growing. We are expanding our service radius from 200 to 250 out because of the one-way market is going up, so we are signing up trucks for longer period because of that, so that's where I get that longer extending out for longer miles and that's growing to some of our base fleet. So that's a ballpark.

headline: J.B. Hunt Transport Services, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2018

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Ben Hartford.

headline: J.B. Hunt Transport Services, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: Want to circle back on the DCS margin question. I know that mentioned the long term, 11% to 13% margin. How should we think about that over the next 5 years or so? To the extent that Final mile does grow, you acknowledge that it's a lower-margin business.
componenttext: Want to circle back on the DCS margin question. I know that mentioned the long term, 11% to 13% margin. How should we think about that over the next 5 years or so? To the extent that Final mile does grow, you acknowledge that it's a lower-margin business. So maybe twofold, is that 11% to 13% still the target, as you assume scaling up the non-asset based network, one, and then two, if it is non-asset based network, is it fair to assume that is a to higher return on invested capital business than the core legacy DCS business?

headline: J.B. Hunt Transport Services, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: Yes, so the way we do our processing and all of it is based on ROIC guidelines. So I'll start reverse of that, talk about the Final Mile, the nonasset portion of that does have a much higher ROIC. So if we grow that, it's going to be growing from a smalle
componenttext: Yes, so the way we do our processing and all of it is based on ROIC guidelines. So I'll start reverse of that, talk about the Final Mile, the nonasset portion of that does have a much higher ROIC. So if we grow that, it's going to be growing from a smaller base at a higher percent. So we'll have some delusion, could be anywhere from 20 to 50 basis points depend on how fast we grow of the overall DCS margin. But I think we can still within DCS, we can still maintain that 11% to 13%, even with that starting to dilute and pull a little bit more as we go forward. But our ROIC on our Dedicated, we cross each one of the deals based on how much of a capital regard to putting in it and hitting our ROIC targets. And so we feel very good about that. But it will have -- Final Mile will have some drag on it, but we still should be able to hit within those guardrails, if you will, of 11% to 13%.

headline: J.B. Hunt Transport Services, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And then, if I can circle back quickly on tariffs. And you mentioned that December could be quite strong given the tariff on January 1. But what our customers saying as it relates to inventory across the channel, to the extent that t
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And then, if I can circle back quickly on tariffs. And you mentioned that December could be quite strong given the tariff on January 1. Has there been any impact aggregate demand outlook to '19 based on these tariffs?

componenttext: So I'll take the acknowledge ment from our CFO that truckload is doing okay. That doesn't happen very often. But truckload, I think is performing. Our prices really came through here in the third quarter. We feel really comfortable with our power mix and our direction moving forward in segment. And we also feel comfortable how they can interact and operate inside of our 360 platform. So that tells that we plan to integrate as well coming into 2019.

headline: J.B. Hunt Transport Services, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: And can you talk a little bit on the driver side, how much wages are up this year across Dedicated, Truckload, Drayage? And then do you expect a similar increase next year, what you've communicated so far about driver wages into '19?
componenttext: And can you talk a little bit on the driver side, how much wages are up this year across Dedicated, Truckload, Drayage? And then do you expect a similar increase next year, what you've communicated so far about driver wages into '19?

headline: J.B. Hunt Transport Services, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: This is David. I'll talk about Dedicated. Probably in the last 12 to 18 months, our driver wages are up about 10% or a little bit more than that. As far as going forward, we each deal depends on where it is and what the demand is and how tight it is in th
componenttext: This is David. I'll talk about Dedicated. Probably in the last 12 to 18 months, our driver wages are up about 10% or a little bit more than that. As far as going forward, we each deal depends on where it is and what the demand is and how tight it is in that particular market. So we price each one of our individual deals based on what we think it would take to recruit drivers. We've been recruiting drivers very well in this difficult market, because of the pay that we've been able to price into our deals for our drivers. So I can't really speculate what it's going to do next year on driver pay. We're just pricing deal by deal.

headline: J.B. Hunt Transport Services, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: And then my question, Shelley mentioned earlier, about customer getting out of spot market where they have got abused this year and into the contract business. Are any of those contracts coming with volume commitments in terms of -- if you're going to put
componenttext: And then my question, Shelley mentioned earlier, about customer getting out of spot market where they have got abused this year and into the contract business. Are any of those contracts coming with volume commitments in terms of -- if you're going to put them under contract and readjust the truck network for them, is it fair that they also commit to give certain number of loads?

headline: J.B. Hunt Transport Services, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: Look, firstly, I don't know that they got abused. In the spot market, the network was completely out of balance. And so there are lots of planning, our loss of planning and more importantly, what the driver market was doing in total really created such a
componenttext: Look, firstly, I don't know that they got abused. In the spot market, the network was completely out of balance. And so there are lots of planning, our loss of planning and more importantly, what the driver market was doing in total really created such a demand that adding and doing things that need they needed to do to service customers. I don't think any of our customers intend to not live up to their commitment. They got to do the job as forecasting, so the crystal ball is very fuzzy for our customers, it's foggy for us as well. Customers are trying to do their very best in estimating how much volume they need to move and they're trying to commit to their carriers based on that. We never have a conversation with the customer. It doesn't come with the commitment and that's really a two-way street.

headline: J.B. Hunt Transport Services, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2018

componenttext: Just I want to turn back to Intermodal. Your comments on the growth turning negative particularly in the train side. componenttextpreview: Well, there's probably 3 or 4 things, I would point you to. One, we talked about the weather events and derailments that we previously mentioned. Last year, we were almost up 8% on the Transcon's, the comp was a little bit difficult. And as we mentioned,
componenttext: Well, there's probably 3 or 4 things, I would point you to. One, we talked about the weather events and derailments that we previously mentioned. Last year, we were almost up 8% on the Transcon's, the comp was a little bit difficult. And as we mentioned, the West Coast was not quite as robust in August and in the first half of September. And then lastly, some of the freight that we lost due to the pricing and the customers did not by our price with regards to long drays, happened to be some of the Transcon freight.

componenttext: Okay. And did you mention, if that's what you saw turning when you mentioned the October outlook, or is that to understand where you are in that process?

componenttext: Great. And then Shelley, for the follow up on your thoughts on negative rates at brokerage. componenttext: No, I would say that's more a contractual relationship that we have that grew more on the LTL side that we're continuing to expand services and cross-sell into our customers. componenttext: I think we're a little out of that range in the latter part of the last year, and I think we've gotten back into that range in the last quarter. So we anticipate to be within that range going forward. And, whether it's higher, lower or in the middle, I can't give you any direction on that. But I think we'll be in that range moving forward.

headline: J.B. Hunt Transport Services, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: All right. And Shelley, just one on the brokerage business. The gross margin sequentially seem to improve on a fairly seasonal basis based on the history that you guys have experienced. Can you talk a little bit about the profit margins you're earning on
componenttext: All right. And Shelley, just one on the brokerage business. The gross margin sequentially seem to improve on a fairly seasonal basis based on the history that you guys have experienced. Can you talk a little bit about the profit margins you're earning on the transactional versus the contractual side today coming out of bid season? How wide is that gap, which one is in favor and what does that mean for the overall gross margin of the business as we move forward?

headline: J.B. Hunt Transport Services, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: Well, on our contractual business, we've been going through repairing that business and recouping costs that we paid out to carriers on a more real-time basis. So certainly those margins have improved as the year has progressed. Our spot margin in total r
componenttext: Well, on our contractual business, we've been going through repairing that business and recouping costs that we paid out to carriers on a more real-time basis. So certainly those margins have improved as the year has progressed. Our spot margin in total revenue per load in sport is generally higher, because that's more out-of-pattern shipments. Longer length fall, margins tend to be slightly better and definitely less volatile. We typically stay in the 14% to 16% range on spot margin in total, and then price continue to repair as the quarter moved forward.

headline: J.B. Hunt Transport Services, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: Question for you on the Intermodal growth. It feels like the rail network really talking the yards are really constraining your ability to kind of grow with that market. Can you comment a little about how rail service is progressing and what kind of the i
componenttext: Question for you on the Intermodal growth. It feels like the rail network really talking the yards are really constraining your ability to kind of grow with that market. Can you comment a little about how rail service is progressing and what kind of the industry or shippers need to do to help kind of increase the fluidity of intermodal traffic, so that it can actually accommodate more growth?

headline: J.B. Hunt Transport Services, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's kind of a two-part question. The rail service isn't where the railroads wanted, it's not where we wanted and it's certainly not where the customers want it. But if you look at history, when they kind of -- their services has degraded. You normal
componenttext: Yes, it's kind of a two-part question. The rail service isn't where the railroads wanted, it's not where we wanted and it's certainly not where the customers want it. But if you look at history, when they kind of -- their services has degraded. You normally don't see it more than 18 to 24 months, so I think, hopefully, next year they'll start coming up out of that. I know there is a lot of things with the railroad being a variety of commodities and that they have always been able to recover. The velocity is key to them as especially at the start looking at precision railroading and they make more money with better velocity typically than they do with slow velocity. so and answer your question about terminals, and what the customers can do. The flexibility that the customers can have with regards to be able to deliver freight 24/7 will allow us, and to be able to clear those terminals quicker, better, and the lower open windows they have to deliver that freight, the quickly there will be able to pull it and deliver to them and that will allow more fluidity in the rail system.

headline: J.B. Hunt Transport Services, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: So you're not worried about capacity on railroads kind of concerning growth into '19 then?
componenttext: So you're not worried about capacity on railroads kind of concerning growth into '19 then?

componenttext: Not at this point, no. I think they'll going to make the appropriate plans, and we will work with them to get those terminals, liquid customers to get that freight picked up and delivered accordingly.

componenttext: Great, great. I have a question with the shipper behavior and truckload question or probably also intermodal question. And the question is, as rates have moved up over the last year or so, one of the issues, of course, has been drivers waiting around and as the power has shifted, if you will, from shipper to provider, one would expect that you guys and others have less tolerance for that. And I'm wondering, are you seeing a lot of shipper behavior change, how many of them feel were not doing a good job and when those -- how many of those are doing the better job, how much productivity benefit you get? So any color around changes in shipper behavior that you guys have seen across the business.

componenttext: I think as customers have become more knowledgeable about where we are at our as an industry with drivers specifically for J.B. Hunt. They want to know what they can do to help. They have probably the greatest awareness of what the facilities look like. Shippers are wanting to be a shipper of choice and so I would say, a large part of our shippers are trying new things and thinking about driver is going to be the way they treat the drivers on dock. So we have seen a movement of that. Can I say what percentage in the past, I think, as transportation cost have reached other companies press releases, it has gotten the attention, all the way up to the of our customers and's those that are over our customers location also are trying to figure out transportation trying to manage cost. headline: J.B. Hunt Transport Services, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: The first one and the last one. Just a quick ones here. One is, when it was out there earlier this year, truck orders -- new truck quarters weren't at the level where they have been for the last several months. Obviously the outlook for intermodal outlook
componenttext: The first one and the last one. Just a quick ones here. One is, when it was out there earlier this year, truck orders -- new truck quarters weren't at the level where they have been for the last several months. Obviously the outlook for intermodal outlook in prices is very strong. But could you guys talk about how the record truck orders have changed for review at all about next year rolling your pricing trajectory for intermodal, I guess, more appropriately probably for the second half of next year. And I know it's a little bit of a crystal ball question, but I would imagine that it would have had some effect in terms of how do you think the cycle plays out?

headline: J.B. Hunt Transport Services, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think it's a little early to tell on that. As I mentioned earlier in the call that the differential between truck price and the Intermodal price will include fuel has widened. I think the line haul pricing that we may have kept up with that in most
componenttext: Yes, I think it's a little early to tell on that. As I mentioned earlier in the call that the differential between truck price and the Intermodal price will include fuel has widened. I think the line haul pricing that we may have kept up with that in most cases, but the fuel cost has widened. So the gap between truck and intermodal versus this time last year has widened. So the question will be the truck rate come down, but then you had all the pressures that are on truck. I don't perceive seeing that come down. So I don't believe early on in '19, it should have really any effect, except wait and see with regards to what happens with truck pricing. Even if truck pricing comes down a little bit, which I don't think is going to happen, there is still a large gap between truck and intermodal.

headline: J.B. Hunt Transport Services, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: Okay. Let me just ask one follow up for David. I don't know, if I heard this correctly, but the September intermodal volume was negative. If I'm not mistaken, I think, the overall comp in September actually was pretty easy, I could be wrong, but plus 1% S
componenttext: Okay. Let me just ask one follow up for David. I don't know, if I heard this correctly, but the September intermodal volume was negative. If I'm not mistaken, I think, the overall comp in September actually was pretty easy, I could be wrong, but plus 1% September last year. Can you just talk about why that comp turned negative in September despite the comp being so easy?

headline: J.B. Hunt Transport Services, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: Yes, there were 2 or 3 things and I had mentioned earlier, the West Coast was not as robust as what it was last year. The -- of course the weather events happened in September and the major developments on the effect what happened in the early September p
componenttext: Yes, there were 2 or 3 things and I had mentioned earlier, the West Coast was not as robust as what it was last year. The -- of course the weather events happened in September and the major developments on the effect what happened in the early September plus some of the final bids that were implemented that had long dray rates that we weren't able to retain, started showing up in August and September.

headline: J.B. Hunt Transport Services, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: Got it. Okay. And then one last one for me on the Dedicated business. Would there be designing the growth initiatives have been organic so far, would there be any appetite to, I guess, bulk up in that business via acquisitions?
componenttext: Got it. Okay. And then one last one for me on the Dedicated business. Would there be designing the growth initiatives have been organic so far, would there be any appetite to, I guess, bulk up in that business via acquisitions?

componenttextpreview: I think on the Dedicated side, we've got a roster of 35-plus salespeople out there. And our toplines are full. And so I see no reason to pay a premium to grow when we can do it organically.
componenttext: I think on the Dedicated side, we've got a roster of 35-plus salespeople out there. And our toplines are full. And so I see no reason to pay a premium to grow when we can do it organically.

componenttext: Dave $800 million or close to $800 million in CapEx that you talked about spending this year with the boost from all the dedicated growth that you've been able to achieve year. Historically, you have been talked about closer to $500 million like normal year. How far down closer to that, that we look next year based on what we know today?

headline: J.B. Hunt Transport Services, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: I think if you look at where our fleet size is and when I say fleet, I'm referring to the consolidated fleet. Yes, my guess is $500 million as a norm is probably inching its way up that you're going to talk about replacement CapEx and normal growth CapEx
componenttext: I think if you look at where our fleet size is and when I say fleet, I'm referring to the consolidated fleet. Yes, my guess is $500 million as a norm is probably inching its way up that you're going to talk about replacement CapEx and normal growth CapEx combined is probably going to look closer to the $650 million from the old $500 million. We have been inching up for the last couple of years on that, anyway, but yes, I have to wait and see what my trade cycle looks like for the next 2 to 3 years and then add to that what I would consider normal growth in intermodal and dedicated, would be more normal CapEx number would be. But I think we moved off the $500 million just given our general size.

headline: J.B. Hunt Transport Services, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2018

componenttext: Understood. And has the return profile you're targeting straight from the kind of, call it 20% returns on capital you generated

componenttext: No, it hasn't. It has not as a matter of fact that even though we are seeing solid record-type growth number inside dedicated, the return profile that those growth numbers are throwing off is not diluting what intermodal return profile and tran-08 return profile should be. So at this point in time, I would say that we are not willing to move after dart through 20% ROIC for the consolidated group.

componenttext: In the current period, Ken, no, we have not deviated from any of our plans. Their trucks that we wanted to bring on for the dray group, we're bringing on in training frankly, during this quarter as well as planned. The box count that we expected to bring on, we're sticking with and not deviating from that. Frankly, we kind of need them because our returns have not been the greatest. So we certainly don't want to give opportunity for growth just because we don't have an extra box or we shortened ourselves boxes accordingly. I think we make modifications that will go into the '19 budget process, and we haven't made those determinations yet.

componenttext: Both, it could go either way. If you have a growth target then we think the growth target can be satisfied from the elasticity that we already have in our equipment, and we may make that decision on the other hand. If you see that this is going to be a steady growth target more than 1-year period in time then we are not heading into actual downturn from an economic standpoint, yes, I wouldn't anticipate us not showing growth boxes in '19 as well.

headline: J.B. Hunt Transport Services, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: Leverage, I think, our attitude has remained the same. As a unwritten rule, we've always kind of targeted 1x EBITDA as relative, safe, prudent debt levels. I wouldn't expect us to deviate that in any material way. Naturally, we could be little bit higher
componenttext: Leverage, I think, our attitude has remained the same. As a unwritten rule, we've always kind of targeted 1x EBITDA as relative, safe, prudent debt levels. I wouldn't expect us to deviate that in any material way. Naturally, we could be little bit higher in one period and a little bit lower in another period, but I think, we always come back towards 1x EBITDA as a target, and if you get substantially lower than the 1x EBITDA, we certainly consider that excess cash, and we have been active in our share repurchase, but I don't see any real reason to accelerate that on that, if we start seeing additional EBITDA over our debt levels.

Okay, Donna, I think, if that's the case, I think, we'll call it early and call it early. Thank you all for joining us, and have a good evening.

headline: J.B. Hunt Transport Services, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: Ladies and gentlemen, please welcome your speaker for today, Mr. David Mee. Sir, you may begin.
componenttext: Ladies and gentlemen, please welcome your speaker for today, Mr. David Mee. Sir, you may begin.

headline: J.B. Hunt Transport Services, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Donna. Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for joining us. We have here, John Roberts, President and CEO; Terry Matthews, President of Intermodal; Nick Hobbs, President of DCS; Shelley Simpson, Chief Commercial Officer and President of High
componenttext:
Thank you, Donna. Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for joining us. We have here, John Roberts, President and CEO; Terry Matthews, President of Intermodal; Nick Hobbs, President of DCS; Shelley Simpson, Chief Commercial Officer and President of Highway Services; and myself, David Mee. 
Given that this is our first earnings call, let me kind of go over what we'd like the format to be. I'll make a brief opening statements and then we'll open up the lines for Q&A. The participants will have an opportunity to ask a question and then one follow up, before they have to return to the end of the queue to give everybody a shot at asking the questions that they want. We do have a call scheduled for 90 minutes. So we hope to get through as many questions as we can during that time. And we do appreciate your patience, given that this is the first time we've attempted this. As we go forward, I'm sure, it will be a lot more efficient into the future.
As far as the opening remarks, I have 2 areas that I want to address. The first is the quarterly tax rate and the difference between the preannounced after-tax charge and the actual after-tax charge reported in the earnings release. The primary culprits in the reduced rates are our annual computation of what is referred to as our FIN 48 exposure, and a tax rate adjustment for equity-based compensation. 
At the time of the arbitration update announcement last week, we had not performed these reconciliations and had not determined the discrete item amounts. So we used our previous estimated quarterly tax rate of 26% instead of the 20.4% that Q3 ultimately generated. With this third quarter adjustment and our current estimate of what our discrete items will be in the fourth quarter, we anticipate that our full year 2018 tax rate will be 24%.
The second area is, obviously, the elephant in the room, the arbitration update. And as we announced, we received the interim award on October 5, 2018. The interim award is subject to a protective order, addressing among other things, confidentiality of the award and the underlying contract. However, in that interim award, we were able to identify a quantifiable claim for a specific issue that accrued over a multiple period, that was the $18 million pretax charge we announced. We also stated that the arbitration panelists requested additional submissions from the parties over the next several months. These submissions are needed to determine, a, an appropriate interim award or awards; and b, a final award. We cannot determine any further financial implications of the interim award beyond the announced $18 million pretax charge, until after the arbitrators review the additional information required to be submitted and issue an additional interim award or final award. Once we can determine any additional financial impact of any interim award or final awards, we will provide additional disclosure at that time.
Until then, we will follow what has been our standard practice during this entire process, which is, what we said in the press release is all we're going to say. So any questions on the arbitration process or on this interim award will most likely be answered with no comment, it is confidential what we have said all we're going to say or something similar. 
Now as we do when the investor community visits our headquarters, we've assembled the entire management team to answer your questions and talk about their businesses. 
With that, Donna, we're now ready to take our first question.

componenttextpreview: First one is just if you can talk about the deceleration in Intermodal volume growth, basically every quarter this year I fully understand that we have the derailment in the quarter, which likely impacted the number. But does the deceleration, I would ima
componenttext: First one is just if you can talk about the deceleration in Intermodal volume growth, basically every quarter this year I fully understand that we have the derailment in the quarter, which likely impacted the number. But does the deceleration, I would imagine impact some price over volume focus from the management team, could you just talk about that? When do you guys expect? You did pull the volume lever or volumes to reaccelerate, just given the tight truckload market?

headline: J.B. Hunt Transport Services, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is Terry Matthews. We, obviously, this year, we've been focused a lot on price, and I think you're seeing the results of that in the marketplace. It's been a marketplace that I believe has been the most orderly marketplace I've seen in the 28 ye
componenttext: Yes, this is Terry Matthews. We, obviously, this year, we've been focused a lot on price, and I think you're seeing the results of that in the marketplace. It's been a marketplace that I believe has been the most orderly marketplace I've seen in the 28 years I've been involved in Intermodal and I think that will continue into next year. With regards to volume, as you look in 2019, I think, you'll see a better balance between price and volume as we go forward and we'll have a more balanced approach as we hit 2019.

headline: J.B. Hunt Transport Services, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: Could you talk about what the -- what you estimate the volume impact to be from the 5 major derailments in the quarter?
componenttext: Could you talk about what the -- what you estimate the volume impact to be from the 5 major derailments in the quarter?

componenttext: I believe it was around 4,000, 5,000 units.

componenttext: Got it. That's helpful. And just as a follow-up, I guess, it was nice to see that step up in incremental margins in the third quarter over 20% kind of an underlying basis. Is that the right level to expect kind of over the next 3, 4 quarters, just given, as some of the pricing actions continue to cycle through the numbers. Is that sort of the right incremental margins you guys are targeting for the Intermodal business over the next several quarters?

headline: J.B. Hunt Transport Services, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: I think that's going -- I mean, this is David Mee. I think that's going to be the result, given that the fact is that we will begin a new pricing calendar here in the fourth quarter, but the effects of those new pricings won't show up until later in the 2
componenttext: I think that's going -- I mean, this is David Mee. I think that's going to be the result, given that the fact is that we will begin a new pricing calendar here in the fourth quarter, but the effects of those new pricings won't show up until later in the 2019. So yes, I would say that the pricing is set. So operationally, if we can squeeze a little bit more margin out of it, out of operations, then we will. But I wouldn't expect much difference in what you've seen here in Q3.

componenttext: Got it. And then a quick follow-up as well. I think that the way this data came out just this morning about spot truck rates continuing to fall. Do you guys think that this is mainly because of a pull forward of freight, which created kind of an artificial high, which we're now seeing to tail off? Or maybe do you think there's something else at work that's causing these spot trucking rates to continue to fall?

headline: J.B. Hunt Transport Services, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2018
componenttextpreview: Great question. This is Shelley. We have similar questions. We have been talking with our customers. We do know that some customers have done a full forward strategy, but I can't say that we've got a great answer to what that question is. We have confirme
componenttext: Great question. This is Shelley. We have similar questions. We have been talking with our customers. We do know that some customers have done a full forward strategy, but I can't say that we've got a great answer to what that question is. We have confirmed our customers are expecting a good peak retail season that they are still considering to be good and so we would expect to have a pretty good peak as we come into Intermodal, finishing the first leg and then truckload coming after that.
